Articles.Content: Okay is the NASA pack going to be free or is it going to be a add on? I'm just a bit confused by its name Pack. In my mind a pack is added content and not included in the base game. Hoping its free. Please squad make it free;)

Copy&pasted from the other thread:

As far as we've been told, the NASA Asteroid Retrieval Mission pack is a free official addon, similar to a mod but made by Squad, not the community. It will be a separate download and not distributed with the main game.

However, some things that only exist because of said mission, such as the SLS-inspired rocket parts, are said to be included in the base game.

All of this should be taken with a grain of salt because even if this was a fully official statement from a few weeks ago, things can change during active development and what it ultimately turns out to be, we'll know for sure no sooner than the day it is released.

Honestly MR4Y, I don't see how this is a bad thing. Yes, the NASA pack can be classified as DLC but only if you take it in the most literal interpretation you give to it. Squad got the opportunity to work with NASA to develop new content for the game and educate people about spaceflight, I honestly don't see what's bad about that. Sure, you could argue that the NASA pack takes away development time from the rest of the game but honestly can you really say that that hurts the game? With the pack you'll get asteroids, new parts, new game mechanics.. it's just like a regular update to the game apart from the fact that it has to be downloaded and installed separately, I suspect because NASA is a government organization and can't give this level of support to a paid commercial product (hence release it as a mod, which is -technically- free).

This also doesn't mean that the devs aren't finishing the game - they're still working on it, the NASA pack is a bonus in my opinion. Why? Because it'll give you more, free content.

And....A round of applause for the first alpha to have DLC.

Jumping the gun before the gun it's even finished.

From the latest news (and also this) it looks like NASA pack will be simply an another update for KSP, and not a separate "mission pack" as it was planned before. Besides... it is free, so it doesn't matter in which form we would get it - but full integration into the stock game is more preferable of course, and fortunately it looks like this is what we getting.

I just find it interesting, the extremes people will go to, to find even the smallest thing to feign poutrage over. I wish I could roll back time, and have you kids sit on on the Hellgate: London alpha and beta tests. Whack was there. Let me put it this way: That beta is the baseline I measure from. A beta so soul crushingly horrible, that there was no intentional malfeasance capable of making it any worse! Imagine this: As a pseudoholiday event, critters drop british halloween candies. Which cannot be used, do not stack in your inventory, and cannot be deleted. Congratulations! You know have an inventory full of nothing. Bug reported, devs aware, and resolution comes... three months later. So for three whole months, the game was unplayable because things you couldn't dodge would clog your inventory.

Context people. I'll have free asteroids to land on Kerbin and smash into things over an inventory full of treacle any day of the week.
The real question is: Is it safe?
